word.entryDescription: killing and eating humans
word.entryExample: It's a true story about a man who tries to protect man-eating sharks from being hunted even though he was bitten by one.

word.entryDescription: being in charge of an organisation or part of an organisation
word.entryExample: I have experience in most aspects of restaurant work, including managing a small café for three months last summer.

word.entryDescription: = compulsory (necessary by law, rule or order)
word.entryExample: It is mandatory for motorcyclists to wear crash helmets.

word.entryDescription: a round tropical fruit with a thin yellow, green or red skin and a juicy yellow flesh
word.entryExample: This mango is juicy and delicious.

word.entryDescription: polite ways of behaving
word.entryExample: I only told the boy it's bad manners to text at meal times.

word.entryDescription: a drawing of an area which shows countries, rivers, roads, cities, etc
word.entryExample: Polly dropped the treasure map into the sea.

word.entryDescription: an area of water beside land, where small, private boats can stay
word.entryExample: Joanna has been living in the same marina for a few years.

word.entryDescription: a number or letter which shows how good or bad your work is
word.entryExample: What's the highest mark you've ever got in school?

word.entryDescription: a place where lots of people sell things at different tables
word.entryExample: You can buy fruit and vegetables at the market.

word.entryDescription: the total demand for a product or service in the market
word.entryExample: More houses should be built to meet the market demands.

word.entryDescription: an open area or square in a town where a market is set up.
word.entryExample: Nowhere did the coinage circulate faster than it did here in the marketplace.

word.entryDescription: (usuallly plural) things painted or written on something, e.g. a road, an aircraft, a vehicle
word.entryExample: I don't understand this marking on the road.

word.entryDescription: a thing worn on the face to protect it, to hide it, or for fun
word.entryExample: You can hide your facial features under a mask.

word.entryDescription: one large amount of something
word.entryExample: Tornadoes only occur when the spinning funnel separates from a big cloud mass.

word.entryDescription: to rub and press the body, usually with the hands, in order to treat pain or help somebody relax
word.entryExample: She's having her feet massaged.

word.entryDescription: to learn a skill so well that you have no difficulty with it
word.entryExample: I have never mastered walking on stilts.

word.entryDescription: a small piece of strong material that covers and protects part of a floor
word.entryExample: There's a mat in front of the sofa.

word.entryDescription: a sports event in which two teams or people play against each other
word.entryExample: West Hill School won the football match.

word.entryDescription: to go together or to look good together
word.entryExample: He's wearing a suit. The trousers and jacket match.

word.entryDescription: a thing that is used for making or doing something
word.entryExample: A video can be a really good teaching material.

word.entryDescription: the study of numbers
word.entryExample: Maths is a very important subject.

word.entryDescription: an amount of food which is usually eaten at certain times of the day
word.entryExample: I eat three meals every day: breakfast, lunch and dinner.

word.entryDescription: an idea represented by a word, sentence, sign, etc.
word.entryExample: We used to repeat sentences and lists of words again and again which I didn't know the meaning of.

word.entryDescription: while something else is happening
word.entryExample: The jury is deliberating. Meanwhile, you must be patient.

word.entryDescription: to find the size, length, or amount of something
word.entryExample: You can measure temperature with a thermometer.

word.entryDescription: food which comes from the flesh of animals
word.entryExample: I don't eat meat.

word.entryDescription: somebody who repairs machines and vehicles
word.entryExample: Is your dad a mechanic?

word.entryDescription: a small flat piece of metal on a long ribbon given to the winners of a sports competition, and usually to those in second and third place
word.entryExample: The winner gets a gold medal.

word.entryDescription: a person who has won a medal in a competition
word.entryExample: He's a double Olympic gold medallist.

word.entryDescription: a substance used to treat a health problem, or the study and treatment of health problems
word.entryExample: Should I take some medicine?

word.entryDescription: spending time in a silent, calm state, in order to relax completely or for religious purposes
word.entryExample: At the beginnig of the film we can see a yogi meditating by a river.

word.entryDescription: of a medium (between big and small) build
word.entryExample: Barry is an average looking young man – medium height and medium build.

word.entryDescription: to arrange to go to a place and see another person
word.entryExample: Meet me at the sports centre at 10 o'clock.

word.entryDescription: to meet someone (e.g. friends) in order to do something together
word.entryExample: She's meeting up with her friends after school to go shopping.

word.entryDescription: a unit of computer information equal to 1024 kilobytes
word.entryExample: A megabyte of data can roughly be a 1 megapixel bitmap image with 256 colours.

word.entryDescription: a very large shop, especially selling one type of product (e.g. computers), usually a part od a chain
word.entryExample: My mum and dad like shopping at megastores.

word.entryDescription: to turn from solid to liquid
word.entryExample: Look, the snowman is beginnig to melt.

word.entryDescription: worth remembering
word.entryExample: I would thoroughly recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for an enjoyable and memorable experience.

word.entryDescription: a small memory device that can be used to store computer data and to move it from one computer to another
word.entryExample: Sam could have saved his homework to a memory stick.

word.entryDescription: a list of the food and drink served in a café or restaurant
word.entryExample: The menu was really varied, but I don't think the food was fresh. The vegetables tasted tinned.

word.entryDescription: to spoil or ruin something, especially something important
word.entryExample: I messed up really badly on the IT Skills test yesterday.

word.entryDescription: made of metal
word.entryExample: You can choose cotton, metal, leather or plastic straps.

word.entryDescription: done in a careful, logical way
word.entryExample: He has a careful, methodical approach to his work.

word.entryDescription: a unit for measuring length or distance; 100 centimetres
word.entryExample: A football pitch is 105 metres long.

word.entryDescription: of or from Mexico
word.entryExample: Have you ever eaten in a Mexican restaurant?

word.entryDescription: an oven which heats food quickly using special waves of energy
word.entryExample: Judith has a microwave for warming food.

word.entryDescription: 12 o'clock in the middle of the day
word.entryExample: I have a coffee break at midday.

word.entryDescription: a period of European history roughly lasting from the 6th to the 15th century, but often used to refer to the later part between the 11th and 15th centuries
word.entryExample: The Middle Ages began after the fall of the Roman Empire.

word.entryDescription: the name between your first name and your family name
word.entryExample: His middle name is James.

word.entryDescription: a football player who usually plays in the middle of the football field
word.entryExample: He's the Arsenal midfielder.
